member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Api.strtoi(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts part of string to int. Returns the int value. Returns 0 if the string is null, "" or does not begin with a number; then numberEndIndex will be = startIndex. Returns int.MaxValue or int.MinValue if the value is not in int range; then numberEndIndex will also include all number characters that follow the valid part.
member.param: String.
Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends.

If 0, parses the string as hexadecimal number if begins with "0x", as octal if begins with "0", else as decimal. Else it can be 2 to 36. Examples: 10 - parse as decimal (don't support "0x" etc); 16 - as hexadecimal (eg returns 26 if string is "1A" or "0x1A"); 2 - as binary (eg returns 5 if string is "101").

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Api.strtoui(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts part of string to uint. Returns the uint value. Returns 0 if the string is null, "" or does not begin with a number; then numberEndIndex will be = startIndex. Returns uint.MaxValue (0xffffffff) or uint.MinValue (0) if the value is not in uint range; then numberEndIndex will also include all number characters that follow the valid part. Supports negative number values -1 to -int.MaxValue, for example converts string "-1" to 0xffffffff.
member.param: String.
Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends.

If 0, parses the string as hexadecimal number if begins with "0x", as octal if begins with "0", else as decimal. Else it can be 2 to 36. Examples: 10 - parse as decimal (don't support "0x" etc); 16 - as hexadecimal (eg returns 26 if string is "1A" or "0x1A"); 2 - as binary (eg returns 5 if string is "101").

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Api.strtoi64(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts part of string to long. Returns the long value. Returns 0 if the string is null, "" or does not begin with a number; then numberEndIndex will be = startIndex. Returns long.MaxValue or long.MinValue if the value is not in long range; then numberEndIndex will also include all number characters that follow the valid part.
member.param: String.
Offset in string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends.

If 0, parses the string as hexadecimal number if begins with "0x", as octal if begins with "0", else as decimal. Else it can be 2 to 36. Examples: 10 - parse as decimal (don't support "0x" etc); 16 - as hexadecimal (eg returns 26 if string is "1A" or "0x1A"); 2 - as binary (eg returns 5 if string is "101").

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.AFFlags
member.summary: Flags for and similar functions.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AFFlags.DirectChild
member.summary: The accessible object must be direct child, not a descendant at any other level. This can be useful when searching in Acc. When searching in Wnd, these are children of the WINDOW object; if using control class name - of control's WINDOW object.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AFFlags.HiddenToo
member.summary: The accessible object can be invisible. Without this flag skips objects that are invisible (have state INVISIBLE) or are descendants of invisible WINDOW, DOCUMENT, PANE, PROPERTYPAGE, GROUPING, ALERT, MENUBAR, TITLEBAR, SCROLLBAR.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AFFlags.MenuToo
member.summary: Always search in MENUITEM. Without this flag skips MENUITEM descendant objects to improve speed, unless role is MENUITEM or MENUPOPUP. Except when used path or when searching in web page or Java window.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AFFlags.Reverse
member.summary: Search in reverse order. It can make faster. When using control class name, controls are searched not in reverse order. Only accessible objects in them are searched in reverse order.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AFFlags.SkipLists
member.summary: Skip descendant objects of OUTLINE (tree view), LIST, TITLEBAR and SCROLLBAR. Objects of OUTLINE and LIST sometimes contain large number of items, which makes finding other objects much slower. See also .

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AFFlags.SkipWeb
member.summary: Skip objects in web pages and DOCUMENT. Objects of these roles often contain large number of descendants, which makes finding other objects much slower. See also .

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AFFlags.WebBusy
member.summary: This flag can be used with role prefix "web:" or "firefox:", when searching in Firefox. It disables waiting while DOCUMENT has BUSY state. This waiting is to improve reliability. However some web pages have busy state always, and it makes the function very slow.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.AFAcc
member.summary: Contains data for callback function (also) of and similar functions. This class is derived from and therefore you can use all Acc properties in callback function. Also has several own properties and methods. The AFAcc variable passed to the callback function is valid only in the callback function. If you need to get normal Acc variable from it (for example to add to a List), use .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.AFAcc.Level
member.summary: 0-based level of this accessible object in the tree of accessible objects. Direct children have level 0, their children have level 1, and so on. When searching in a window or control, at level 0 are direct children of the WINDOW object of the window or control. The WINDOW object itself is not included in the search; if you need it, instead use . When searching in Acc, at level 0 are its direct children. When searching in web page (role has prefix "web:" etc), at level 0 is the root object (DOCUMENT in Firefox/Chrome, PANE in Internet Explorer). When using control class name, at level 0 are direct children of WINDOW objects of matching controls.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.AFAcc.Param
member.summary: With - the param argument. With - the Param property. Probably not useful with Acc.Find. The callback function can use it for any purpose.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.AFAcc.Stop
member.summary: The callback function can call this to stop searching. If the callback function then returns false, it means 'not found'. Don't need to call this if returns true.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.AFAcc.SkipChildren
member.summary: The callback function can call this to skip (don't search) descendants of current accessible object.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.AFAcc.ToAcc
member.summary: Creates new Acc variable from this AFAcc variable. It is a reference to the same accessible object.

member.summary: Sets/clears fields/properties before calling the callback.

member.summary: Accessible object state flags. Used by .
member.remarks: Most names are as in API IAccessible.get_accState documentation but without prefix "STATE_SYSTEM_".

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.AccSELFLAG
member.summary: Accessible object selection flags. Used by .
member.remarks: The names are as in API IAccessible.accSelect documentation but without prefix "SELFLAG_".

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR
member.summary: Accessible object navigation direction. Used by .
member.remarks: The names are as in API IAccessible.accNavigate documentation but without prefix "NAVDIR_". Many objects don't support NEXT, PREVIOUS, FIRSTCHILD, LASTCHILD. Some objects skip invisible siblings. When unavailable, functions of this library try a workaround, which works well with FIRSTCHILD and LASTCHILD, but with NEXT and PREVIOUS it is slow and not always succeeds. Instead you can use PARENT/CHILD. UP, DOWN, LEFT and RIGHT - spatial navigation in the same container object. Rarely supported or useful. String names - "#1", "#2", "#3", "#4".

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR.NEXT
member.summary: Next sibling object in the same parent (container) object. String name - "next", "ne" or "n".

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR.PREVIOUS
member.summary: Previous sibling object in the same parent (container) object. String name - "previous", "pr" or "prev".

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR.FIRSTCHILD
member.summary: First direct child object. String name - "first", "fi" or "f".

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR.LASTCHILD
member.summary: Last direct child object. String name - "last", "la" or "l".

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR.PARENT
member.summary: The parent (container) object. String name - "parent", "pa" or "p". Few objects don't support it. Note: Some Chrome versions have this bug: the parent object does not support .

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR.CHILD
member.summary: A direct child object by 1-based index. String name - "child", "ch" or "c". Negative index means from end, for example -1 is the last child.

member.remarks: The names are as in API documentation but without prefix "WINEVENT_". There are no flags for OUTOFCONTEXT and INCONTEXT. OUTOFCONTEXT is default (0). INCONTEXT cannot be used in managed code.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.Native
member.summary: Windows API types and constants used with public functions (parameters etc) of this library. Also several helper functions.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Native.ClearError
member.summary: Calls API SetLastError(0), which clears the Windows API error code of this thread. Need it before calling some functions if you want to use or GetErrorMessage.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Native.SetError(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API SetLastError, which sets the Windows API error code of this thread.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Native.GetError
member.summary: Gets the Windows API error code of this thread. Calls .
member.remarks:
Many Windows API functions, when failed, set an error code. Code 0 means no error. It is stored in an internal thread-specific int variable. But only if the API declaration's DllImport attribute has SetLastError = true. Some functions of this library simply call these API functions and don't throw exception when API fail. For example, most Wnd propery-get functions. When failed, they return false/0/null/empty. Then you can call Native.GetError to get the error code. Also you can use GetErrorMessage.
Most of these functions set the code only when failed, and don't clear old error code when succeeded. Therefore may need to call before.
Windows API error code definitions and documentation are not included in this library. You can look for them in API function documentation on the internet.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Native.GetErrorMessage
member.summary: Gets the text message of the Windows API error code of this thread. Returns null if the code is 0. The string always ends with ".".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Native.GetErrorMessage(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the text message of a Windows API error code. Returns null if errorCode is 0. The string always ends with ".".

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.SIArea
member.summary: Defines the search area for and similar functions. It can be a window/control, accessible object, Bitmap or a rectangle in screen. Also allows to specify a rectangle in it, which makes the search area smaller and the function faster. Example: ScreenImage.Find("image.png", new SIArea(w, 100, 100, 100, 100));.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.SIFlags
member.summary: Flags for and similar functions.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.SIFlags.WindowDC
member.summary: Get pixels from the device context (DC) of the window client area, not from screen DC. Not used when area is Bitmap. Notes: Usually much faster. Can get pixels from window parts that are covered by other windows or offscreen. But not from hidden and minimized windows. Does not work on Windows 7 if Aero theme is turned off. Then this flag is ignored. If the window is DPI-scaled, the specified image must be captured from its non-scaled version. Cannot find images in some windows (including Windows Store apps), and in some window parts (glass). All pixels captured from these windows/parts are black.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.SIFlags.AllMustExist
member.summary: When the image argument specifies multiple images, all they must exist, else result is "not found". The result rectangle is of the last image. To get all rectangles, use the also parameter: also: t => { rectList.Add(t.Rect); return true; }.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.SIResult
member.summary: Result of and similar functions.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.SIResult.Rect
member.summary: Location of the found image. Relative to the window/control client area (if area type is Wnd), accessible object (if Acc), bitmap (if Bitmap) or screen (if RECT). More info: .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.SIResult.MatchIndex
member.summary: When there are multiple matching images on the screen, this is the 0-based index of current matching image. Can be used in callback function to create action "skip n matching images". Example: also: t => t.MatchIndex==1. When the image argument specifies multiple images, this will start from 0 for each image.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.SIResult.ListIndex
member.summary: When the image argument specifies multiple images, this is the 0-based index of the found image in the list.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.Types`2
member.summary: Used for method parameters that accept one of two types.
member.remarks:
Some methods have one or several parameters that must be one of several types. There are several ways of implementing such functions. 1. Overloaded methods. However some programmers often don't like it, because in some cases need to create many overloads, then maintain their documentation. Also then method users have to spend much time to find the correct overload. 2. Generic methods. However in most cases the compiler cannot protect from using an unsupported type. Also then method users don't see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. 3. Using the Object type for the parameter. However then the compiler does not protect from using an unsupported type. Also then method users don't see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. Also slower, especially with value types (need boxing). 4. Using this type for the parameter. It does not have the above problems.
When a parameter is of type Types<T1, T2>, method users can pass only values of type T1 or T2, else compiler error. They see the allowed types instantly in intellisense. Also there are similar types that can be used to support more parameter types:
To support null (for example for optional parameters), use nullable. See examples.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.Coord
member.summary: Contains x or y coordinate. Used for parameters of functions like Mouse.Move, Wnd.Move. Allows to easily specify coordinates of these types: normal, reverse (from right or bottom of a rectangle), fractional (fraction of width or height of a rectangle), null. Also has functions to convert to normal coodinates.

member.summary: is pixel offset from left or top of a rectangle.

member.summary: is pixel offset from right or bottom of a rectangle, towards left or top.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.Coord.CoordType.Fraction
member.summary: is fraction of a rectangle, where 0.0 is left or top, and 1.0 is right or bottom (outside of the rectangle).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Coord.NormalizeInRect(Catkeys.Types.Coord,Catkeys.Types.Coord,Catkeys.Types.RECT,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts fractional/reverse coordinates to normal coordinates in a rectangle.
member.param: X coordinate relative to r. If default(Coord), returns 0 x.
Y coordinate relative to r. If default(Coord), returns 0 y.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.SRMoreParams
member.summary: More parameters for .

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.SRMoreParams.CurrentDirectory
member.summary: Initial "current directory" for the new process. If this is not set (null), the function gets parent directory path of the specified file that is to run, if possible (if its full path is specified or found). It's because some incorrectly designed programs look for their files in "current directory", and fail to start if initial "current directory" is not set to the program's directory. If this is "" or invalid or the function cannot find full path, the new process will inherit "current directory" of this process.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.SRMoreParams.Verb
member.summary: File's right-click menu command, also known as verb. For example "edit", "print", "properties". The default verb is bold in the menu. Not all menu items will work. Some may have different name than in the menu. Use verb "RunAs" for "Run as administrator".

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.SRMoreParams.OwnerWindow
member.summary: A window that may be used as owner window of error message box. Also, new window should be opened on the same screen. However many programs ignore it.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.SRMoreParams.WindowState
member.summary: Preferred window state. Many programs ignore it.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.SRMoreParams.NeedProcessHandle
member.summary: Get process handle, if possible. The property will contain it.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.SRMoreParams.ProcessHandle
member.summary: This is an [Out] value. When the function returns, if was set to true, contains process handle in a variable. null if did not start new process (eg opened the document in an existing process) or did not get process handle for some other reason. Note: WaitHandle is disposable.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.CatException
member.summary: The base exception used in this library. Some constructors support Windows API error code. Then Message will contain its error description. If the string passed to the constructor starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If does not end with ".", appends ".".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.#ctor
member.summary: Sets Message = "Failed.". Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Sets Message = message. Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets Message = "Failed. " + Native.GetErrorMessage(winApiErrorCode). Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : Native.GetError().

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.#ctor(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + " " + Native.GetErrorMessage(winApiErrorCode). Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : Native.GetError().

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + "\r\n\t" + innerException.Message. Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.#ctor(System.Int32,System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + " " + Native.GetErrorMessage(winApiErrorCode) + "\r\n\t" + innerException.Message. Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : Native.GetError().

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.CatException.NativeErrorCode
member.summary: Gets the Windows API error code.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.CatException.Message
member.summary: Gets error message.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.CatException.FormattedMessage
member.summary: String created by FormatMessage(), which should be called by the Message override if null. Initially null.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.FormatMessage(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Formats error message. Sets and returns FormattedMessage. As base text, uses the text passed to the constructor (default "Failed."). If it starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If it ends with "*", replaces the "*" with commonPostfix if it is not empty. If then the message does not end with ".", appends ".". If appendMessage is null, uses Native.GetErrorMessage(NativeErrorCode) if NativeErrorCode not 0. If then appendMessage is not empty, appends " " and appendMessage. Also appends InnerException.Message in new tab-indented line if InnerException is not null.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.ThrowIfHresultNot0(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: If errorCode is not 0, throws CatException that includes the code and its message. More info: .
member.param: Windows API error code or HRESULT.
Main message. The message of the error code will be appended to it.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.CatException.ThrowIfHresultNegative(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: If errorCode is less than 0, throws CatException that includes the code and its message. More info: .
member.param: Windows API error code or HRESULT.
Main message. The message of the error code will be appended to it.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.WndException
member.summary: Exception thrown mostly by functions.
member.remarks: Some constructors support Windows API error code. Then Message also will contain its error description. If error code ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE, Message also depends on whether the window handle is 0. If parameter 'winApiErrorCode' is 0 or not used: if the window handle is invalid, uses ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE. If the string passed to the constructor starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If ends with "*", replaces the "*" with " window.". If does not end with ".", appends ".".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.WndException.#ctor(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE. Sets Message = "Failed.".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.WndException.#ctor(Catkeys.Wnd,System.String)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.WndException.#ctor(Catkeys.Wnd,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? Native.GetError() : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE). Sets Message = "Failed.".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.WndException.#ctor(Catkeys.Wnd,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? Native.GetError() : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE).

member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.WndException.#ctor(Catkeys.Wnd,System.Int32,System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? Native.GetError() : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE).

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.ISupportOrThrow
member.summary: Adds method to classes that implement this interface. Actually this interface has no methods to implement. Just add ISupportOrThrow to the implemented interfaces list in class declaration. Not used with struct. If you want to add OrThrow to a struct, add it as a normal or extension method of that struct. Example - .

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.LPARAM
member.summary: Similar to IntPtr (can be 32-bit or 64-bit), but more useful for usually-non-pointer values, eg wParam/lParam of SendMessage. Unlike IntPtr: Has implicit casts from/to most integral types. Does not check overflow when casting from uint etc. IntPtr throws exception on overflow, which can create strange bugs.
member.remarks: There is no struct WPARAM. Use LPARAM instead, because it is the same in all cases except when casting to long or ulong (ambigous signed/unsigned). There is no cast operators for enum. When need, cast through int or uint. For Wnd cast through IntPtr.

bottom or height, depending on .

member.summary: Replaces this rectangle with the intersection of itself and the specified rectangle. Returns true if the rectangles intersect. If they don't intersect, makes this RECT empty (IsEmpty would return true).

member.summary: Moves this rectangle by the specified offsets: left+=dx; right+=dx; top+=dy; bottom+=dy; Negative dx moves to the left. Negative dy moves up.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.RECT.Union(Catkeys.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Replaces this rectangle with the union of itself and the specified rectangle. Union is the smallest rectangle that contains two full rectangles. Returns true if finally this rectangle is not empty. If either rectangle is empty (Width or Height is <=0), the result is another rectangle. If both empty - empty rectangle.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.RECT.Union(Catkeys.Types.RECT,Catkeys.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Returns the union of two rectangles. Union is the smallest rectangle that contains two full rectangles. If either rectangle is empty (Width or Height is <=0), the result is another rectangle. If both empty - empty rectangle.

Use this screen (see ). If null (default), uses the primary screen.
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
If part of rectangle is not in screen, move and/or resize it so that entire rectangle would be in screen. Default true.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.Wildex
member.summary: This class implements wildcard expression parsing and matching (comparing). Typically used in 'find' functions. For example, Wnd.Find uses it to compare window name, class name and program. The 'find' function creates a Wildex instance (which parses the wildcard expression), then calls for each item (eg window) to compare some its property text.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Wildcard expression. Cannot be null (throws exception). "" will match "".

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.op_Implicit(System.String)~Catkeys.Types.Wildex
member.summary: Creates new Wildex from wildcard expression string. If the string is null, returns null.
member.param: Wildcard expression.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.Match(System.String)
member.summary: Compares a string with the wildcard expression used to create this . Returns true if they match.
member.param: String. If null, returns false. If "", returns true if it was "" or "*" or a regular expression that matches "".

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.WildType
member.summary: The type of text (wildcard expression) used when creating the Wildex variable.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.WildType.Text
member.summary: Simple text (option t, or no *? characters and no t r options). Match() calls .

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.WildType.Wildcard
member.summary: Wildcard (has *? characters and no t r options). Match() calls .

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.WildType.Regex
member.summary: Regular expression (option r). Match() calls .

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.WildType.Multi
member.summary: Multiple parts (option m). Match() calls Match() for each part (see ) and returns true if all negative (option n) parts return true (or there are no such parts) and some positive (no option n) part returns true (or there are no such parts). If you want to implement a different logic, call Match() for each element (instead of calling Match() for this variable).

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.Text
member.summary: Gets the wildcard or simple text. null if TextType is Regex or Multi.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.Regex
member.summary: Gets the Regex object created from regular expression string. null if TextType is not Regex (no option r).

member.name: P:Catkeys.Types.Wildex.MultiArray
member.summary: Array of Wildex variables, one for each part in multi-part text. null if TextType is not Multi (no option m).

member.summary: Gets the type of text (wildcard, regex, etc).

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FAFlags.DoNotThrow
member.summary: If failed, return false and don't throw exception. Then, if you need error info, you can use . If the file/directory does not exist, it will return ERROR_FILE_NOT_FOUND or ERROR_PATH_NOT_FOUND or ERROR_NOT_READY. If failed and the native error code is ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED or ERROR_SHARING_VIOLATION, the returned attributes will be (FileAttributes)(-1). The file probably exists but is protected so that this process cannot access and use it. Else attributes will be 0.

member.summary: Enumerate subdirectories too.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FEFlags.SkipHidden
member.summary: Skip files and subdirectories that have Hidden attribute.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FEFlags.SkipHiddenSystem
member.summary: Skip files and subdirectories that have Hidden and System attributes (both). These files/directories usually are created and used only by the operating system. Drives usually have several such directories. Another example - thumbnail cache files. Without this flag the function skips only these hidden-system root directories when enumerating a drive: "$Recycle.Bin", "System Volume Information", "Recovery". If you want to include them too, use network path of the drive, for example @"\\localhost\D$\" for D drive.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FEFlags.IgnoreAccessDeniedErrors
member.summary: If fails to get contents of the directory or a subdirectory because of its security settings, assume that the [sub]directory is empty. Without this flag then throws exception or calls errorHandler.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FEFlags.DisableRedirection
member.summary: Temporarily disable file system redirection in this thread of this 32-bit process running on 64-bit Windows. Then you can enumerate the 64-bit System32 folder in your 32-bit process. Uses API Wow64DisableWow64FsRedirection. For vice versa (in 64-bit process enumerate the 32-bit System folder), instead use path Folders.SystemX86.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FEFlags.UseRawPath
member.summary: Don't call (directoryPath) and don't throw exception for non-full path.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FEFlags.NeedRelativePaths
member.summary: Let be path relative to the specified directory path. Like @"\name.txt" or @"\subdirectory\name.txt" instead of "name.txt".

member.name: T:Catkeys.Types.FCFlags
member.summary: flags for and some other similar functions. Used only when copying directory.

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FCFlags.SkipHiddenSystem
member.summary: Skip descendant files and directories that have Hidden and System attributes (both). They usually are created and used only by the operating system. Drives usually have several such directories. Another example - thumbnail cache files. They often are protected and would fail to copy, ruining whole copy operation. Without this flag the function skips only these hidden-system root directories when enumerating a drive: "$Recycle.Bin", "System Volume Information", "Recovery".

member.name: F:Catkeys.Types.FCFlags.IgnoreAccessDeniedErrors
member.summary: If fails to get contents of the directory or a subdirectory because of its security settings, don't throw exception but assume that the [sub]directory is empty.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Acc
member.summary: Accessible object.
member.remarks:
Accessible objects are various user interface (UI) objects in windows and controls. For example buttons, links, list items. This class can find them, get properties, click, etc. Especially useful with web pages, because there are no controls. And many other windows don't use controls but support accessible objects. But not all UI objects are accessible objects.
An Acc instance holds an accessible object COM pointer (IAccessible) and a child element id (int). Most Acc functions wrap IAccessible interface functions or/and related API.
Acc functions that get properties don't throw exception when the wrapped IAccessible/etc function failed (returned an error code of HRESULT type). Then they return default value of that type (null, 0, false); string property getters return "". Various accessible objects in various applications are implemented differently, often with bugs, and their IAccessible interface functions return a variety of error codes. It's impossible to reliably detect whether the error code means a serious error or the property is merely unavailable. These Acc functions also set the last error code of this thread = the return value (HRESULT) of the IAccessible function, and callers can use to get it. If Native.GetError returns 1 (S_FALSE), in most cases it's not an error, just the property is unavailable. On error it will probably be a negative error code.
Disposing Acc variables (to release the COM object) is not necessary (GC will do it later), but in libraries it is recommended.
Supports accessible objects of Java windows if the Java Access Bridge (JAB) is enabled. You can enable/disable it in Control Panel -> Ease of Access Center -> Use the computer without a display. Or use jabswitch.exe.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.WndContainer
member.summary: Gets the container window or control of this accessible object. Uses API WindowFromAccessibleObject.
member.remarks: Returns default(Wnd) if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property, but some have bugs and can fail (return default(Wnd)) or return a wrong window.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.WndTopLevel
member.summary: Gets the top-level window that contains this accessible object. Uses API WindowFromAccessibleObject and API GetAncestor.
member.remarks: Returns default(Wnd) if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property, but some have bugs and can return default(Wnd).

member.summary: Gets location of this accessible object in screen.
member.remarks: Calls . Returns empty rectangle if failed or this property is unavailable. Supports . Most but not all objects support this property.

member.param: Receives object rectangle in screen coordinates.

member.param: Receives object rectangle in w client area coordinates.
Window or control.
member.remarks: Returns false if failed or this property is unavailable. Supports . Most but not all objects support this property.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.RoleEnum
member.summary: Gets standard non-string role, as enum AccROLE. Uses IAccessible.get_accRole.
member.remarks: Most objects have a standard role, as enum AccROLE. Some objects have a custom role, normally as string. Returns 0 if object's role is string. Returns 0 if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property. If failed, probably the object is invalid, for example its window was closed.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.RoleString
member.summary: Gets standard or custom role, as string. Uses IAccessible.get_accRole.
member.remarks: Most objects have a standard role, as enum . Some objects have a custom role, normally as string, for example in web pages in Firefox and Chrome. For standard roles this function returns enum member name. For string roles - the string. For unknown non-string roles - the int value like "0" or "500". Returns "" if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property. If failed, probably the object is invalid, for example its window was closed.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.State
member.summary: Gets object state (flags). Uses IAccessible.get_accState.
member.remarks: Returns 0 if failed. Supports . Getting state often is slower than getting role, name or rectangle. But usually not much slower.

example.code: if(a.State.Has_(AccSTATE.INVISIBLE)) Print("invisible"); if(a.IsInvisible) Print("invisible"); //the same as above

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsBusy
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.BUSY. Can be used with DOCUMENT object of web browsers.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsChecked
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.CHECKED.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsDisabled
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.UNAVAILABLE.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsFocused
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.FOCUSED.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsInvisible
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.INVISIBLE.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsOffscreen
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.OFFSCREEN.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsPassword
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.PROTECTED.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsPressed
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.PRESSED.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsReadonly
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.READONLY.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.IsSelected
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has AccSTATE.SELECTED. See also .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets name. Uses IAccessible.get_accName or IAccessible.put_accName.
member.remarks: Object name usually is its read-only text (eg button text or link text), or its adjacent read-only text (eg text label by this edit box). It usually does not change, therefore can be used to find or identify the object. Most objects don't support 'set'. The 'get' function returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.LibNameOfWindow(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets accessible name of window/control w. Returns null if w invalid. Returns "" if failed to get name.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets value. Uses IAccessible.get_accValue or IAccessible.put_accValue.
member.remarks: Object value usually is its editable text or some other value that can be changed at run time, therefore in most cases it cannot be used to find or identify the object reliably. Most objects don't support 'set'. The 'get' function returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.Description
member.summary: Gets description. Uses IAccessible.get_accDescription.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.Help
member.summary: Gets help text. Uses IAccessible.get_accHelp.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.KeyboardShortcut
member.summary: Gets keyboard shortcut. Uses IAccessible.get_accKeyboardShortcut.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.DefaultAction
member.summary: Gets default action. Uses IAccessible.get_accDefaultAction.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . This function may have problems with Java windows. Then instead use .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.JavaActions
member.summary: Gets list of actions that can be used with .

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.Navigate(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets another accessible object that is somehow related to this object (child, parent, next, etc). Allows to specify multiple relations.
member.param: String consisting of one or more navigation direction strings separated by space, like "parent next child4 first". Navigation string reference and more info: . A string can end with a number, like "child4" or "child,4". It is the n parameter of . A custom direction can be specified like "#0x1009".
Dispose this Acc variable (release the COM object).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.Navigate(Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets another accessible object that is somehow related to this object (child, parent, next, etc). Returns null if not found. You can use (see example).
member.param: Navigation direction (relation). For example AccNAVDIR.PARENT. Custom directions also are supported. For example (AccNAVDIR)0x1009. More info is in documentation.

With navDir AccNAVDIR.CHILD it is 1-based child index. Negative index means from end, for example -1 is the last child. Cannot be 0. With all other navDir - how many times to get object in the specified direction. For example PARENT 2 will get parent's parent. Cannot be less than 1.
Dispose this Acc variable (release the COM object).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.DoDefaultAction
member.summary: Asks the accessible object to perform its default action (see ), for example 'click'. Uses IAccessible.accDoDefaultAction.
member.remarks: Fails if the object does not have a default action. Then you can use or try , . If the action takes long time, for example shows a dialog, this function normally just starts the action and returns immediately. It allows the caller to automate the dialog. If it does not return immediately, you can use another thread to automate the dialog.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.DoJavaAction(System.String)
member.summary: Asks the Java accessible object to perform one of its actions.
member.param: Action name. See . If null (default), posts Space key message to the object.
member.remarks: Supports accessible objects of Java windows only if the Java Access Bridge (JAB) is enabled. You can enable/disable it in Control Panel -> Ease of Access Center -> Use the computer without a display. Or use jabswitch.exe. JAB has this bug: if it is a button click action that opens a modal dialog, DoDefaultAction/DoJavaAction do not return until the dialog is closed. It waits max 8 s. During that time the caller must wait and cannot automate the dialog. Also then this process cannot exit until the dialog is closed. If the action parameter is null and the object is focusable, this function tries a workaround: it makes the object (button etc) focused and posts Space key message, which should press the button, and it does not wait.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.Select(Catkeys.Types.AccSELFLAG)
member.summary: Selects or deselects.
member.param: Specifies whether to select, focus, add to selection etc. Can be two flags, for example AccSELFLAG.TAKEFOCUS | AccSELFLAG.TAKESELECTION.
member.remarks: Uses IAccessible.accSelect. Not all objects support it. Most objects support not all flags. It depends on object states FOCUSABLE, SELECTABLE, MULTISELECTABLE, EXTSELECTABLE, DISABLED. Many object have bugs, especially with flag TAKEFOCUS. For example standard Windows controls often deactivate the window etc.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.Focus(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this object focused for keyboard input.
member.param: Focus and select. Adds flag TAKESELECTION. Note: it is for selecting a list item, not for selecting text in a text box.
member.remarks: Calls with flag TAKEFOCUS and optionally TAKESELECTION. Not all objects support this action and not all work correctly. More info in Select documentation.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.SelectedChildren
member.summary: Gets selected direct child items. Returns empty array if there are no selected items of if failed.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Acc._Java._JApi
member.summary: Loads Java Access Bridge (JAB) dll and functions. Allows to call the functions. Need this because 64-bit and 32-bit versions of the dll have different names, and [DllImport] does not support it.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc._Java._IsJavaWindow(Catkeys.Wnd)
member.summary: Returns true if w process has a JAB hidden dialog ("Access Bridge status", "#32770"). It can be a Java window or other window that uses JAB (eg JavaMonkey; but not a window of this process).
member.remarks: speed: faster than AccessibleObjectFromWindow/AccessibleObjectFromPoint. Call once for a top-level window, don't call for controls.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.IAccessible.accHitTest(System.Int32,System.Int32,Catkeys.Acc._Acc@)
member.summary: Gets object from point (screen coordinates), which can be a child (topmost) or self. If neither a child or this is at that point, sets a.iacc=0 and a.elem=0. Returns 1 (S_FALSE). Note: the point can be in objects's bounding rectangle but the object is not rectangular. Else if at that point is this, sets a.iacc=this and a.elem=0. Does not AddRef. Else if at that point is a simple element, sets a.iacc=this and a.elem!=0. Does not AddRef. Else sets a.iacc=child and a.elem=0. Will need to release a.iacc.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.IAccessible.get_accFocus(Catkeys.Acc._Acc@)
member.summary: Gets focused object, which can be a child or this. If neither a child or this is focused, sets a.iacc=0 and a.elem=0. Returns 1 (S_FALSE). Else if focused is this, sets a.iacc=this and a.elem=0. Does not AddRef. Else if focused is a simple element, sets a.iacc=this and a.elem!=0. Does not AddRef. Else sets a.iacc=child and a.elem=0. Will need to release a.iacc.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.IAccessible.accNavigate(Catkeys.Types.AccNAVDIR,System.Int32,Catkeys.Acc._Acc@)
member.summary: Calls accNavigate(out VARIANT) and gets IAccessible/elem from VARIANT using standard pattern which may involve get_accParent/get_accChild. Unlike the higher-level function Acc.Navigate: Does not support PARENT and CHILD. Does not apply a workaround when fails.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.IAccessible.FromVARIANT(Catkeys.Types.VARIANT@,Catkeys.Acc._Acc@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates child IAccessible/elem from VARIANT. If VT_DISPATCH, gets IAccessible and releases the IDispatch. Sets a.elem=0. If VT_I4, sets non-zero a.elem and sets a.a=this. Does not AddRef. Clears the VARIANT (releases IDispatch etc, sets vt=0). Returns HRESULT. If vt is not VT_DISPATCH/VT_I4 or value is 0, asserts and returns E_FAIL.
member.param: The input VARIANT. This function disposes it.
a.a - result IAccessible. If VT_DISPATCH, it is a child of this. If VT_I4, it is this. a.elem - if VT_I4, receives non-zero child id, else 0.
If VT_I4, try to call get_accChild. If it succeeds, sets a.elem = 0.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.IAccessible.FromIDispatch(System.IntPtr,Catkeys.Acc.IAccessible@)
member.summary: Calls QueryInterface to get IAccessible from IDispatch idisp. Releases idisp. Returns HRESULT.
member.param: IDispatch as IntPtr. If == default, returns Api.E_FAIL.
Result.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.Finder.MaxLevel

It prevents stack overflow when an object has a bug and returns itself when queried a child. A smaller level can make faster, because objects at higher levels are not searched. An alternative is to use path.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.Find(Catkeys.Wnd,System.String,System.String,Catkeys.Types.AFFlags,System.Func{Catkeys.Types.AFAcc,System.Boolean},System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Finds accessible object in window. Returns null if not found. You can use (see example).
member.param: Window or control that contains the object.
Accessible object role, like "LINK". See , . Or path consisting of roles, like "ROLE/ROLE/ROLE". More info in Remarks. Case-sensitive, not wildcard. Use null to match any role. Cannot be "".

Accessible object name (). String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. "" means 'must not have name'. Or can be a '\0'-separated list of properties and/or HTML attributes, like "name=xxx\0 a:href=yyy" or "\0 a:href=yyy". The list is passed to . The values are wildcard expressions.

Lambda etc callback function to call for each matching accessible object. Let it return true if this is the object you want. The parameter is of type which has all Acc properties and several own. Example, the object must not be disabled: also: o => !o.IsDisabled Example, the object must have certain Value: also: o => o.Value == "http://www.example.com/x.php" Example, the object's Value must match a wildcard: also: o => o.Value.Like_("start*end") Example, the object must be at certain level in the object tree: also: o => o.Level == 2 Example, the object must contain x y: o => o.GetRect(out var r, o.WndWindow) && r.Contains(266, 33)
0-based index of matching object. For example, if 1, the function skips the first matching object and returns the second.
A navigation string that can be used to get another object related to the found object, like with . This is applied when all other parameters match (including and ).
member.exception: role is "" or invalid. name is invalid wildcard expression ("**options|" or regular expression). Parts of '\0'-separated name string have invalid format or unknown property names. navig is invalid.
member.remarks:
Standard role names are as in the enum. Also can be used custom roles, such as "div" in Firefox. When searching in window, role or path can have one of these prefixes:
"class=X:" - search only in visible child controls whose class name is X (see ). Case-insensitive wildcard, see .
"id=X:" - search only in visible child controls whose id is X (see ).
"web:" - search only in the visible web page, not in whole window. Examples: "web:LINK", "web:DOCUMENT/LIST/LISTITEM/LINK". It usually makes faster. Supports Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer (IE) and apps based on their code. With other windows, searches in the first found visible DOCUMENT object. Chrome web page accessible objects normally are disabled (DOCUMENT does not have children). Use prefix "web:" or "chrome:" to enable them.
"firefox:" - search only in the visible web page of Firefox or Firefox-based web browser. If w window class name starts with "Mozilla", can be used "web:" instead.
"chrome:" - search only in the visible web page of Chrome or Chrome-based web browser. If w window class name starts with "Chrome", can be used "web:" instead.
"java:" - find Java accessible object.
This function walks the tree of accessible objects of the window or control, until it finds a matching object. To make faster, you can use path to the object. Examples:
"web:DOCUMENT/div/LIST/LISTITEM/LINK" - find LINK using its full path in web page.
"web:/div/LIST//LINK" - the empty parts mean 'any role'. For example don't need to specify DOCUMENT because in web pages the first part is always DOCUMENT (Firefox, Chrome) or PANE (IE).
"web:/div/LIST[4]/LISTITEM[-1]/LINK" - the 4 is 1-based index of div child from which to start searching (4-th, then 3-th, 5-th and so on). It can make faster. Negative means 'index from end', for example use -1 to search in reverse order. Flag Reverse is not applied to path parts with indexes. If index is invalid, will use the nearest valid index.
"web:/div/LIST[4!]/LISTITEM[-1!]/LINK" - like the above, but the LIST must be exactly 4-th child (don't search 3-th, 5-th etc) and the LISTITEM must be the last child. This can be useful when waiting (uses less CPU), however useless if object indices in the window or web page change often.
"web://[4]/[-1!]/[2]" - index without role.
"CLIENT/WINDOW/OUTLINE/OUTLINEITEM[-1]" - path in window or control. The first path part is a direct child object of the WINDOW object of the window/control. The WINDOW object itself is not included in the search; if you need it, instead use .
Tip: Instead of literal role string you can use nameof. Example: nameof(AccROLE.CHECKBUTTON).
This function uses a . You can use it directly, it has some more options (see example).
Finding accessible objects can be much slower if this process is 64-bit and that process is 32-bit or vice versa. Finding accessible objects of some applications works well only if this process is 32-bit or only if 64-bit. For example LibreOffice.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.Focused

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.FromEvent(Catkeys.Wnd,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the accessible object that generated the event that is currently being processed by the callback function used with API SetWinEventHook. Returns null if failed. Suports .
member.remarks: The parameters are of the callback function. Uses API AccessibleObjectFromEvent. Often fails because the object already does not exist, because the callback function is called asynchronously, especially when the event is OBJECT_DESTROY, OBJECT_HIDE, SYSTEM_*END. Returns null if failed. Always check the return value, to avoid NullReferenceException. An exception in a callback function used with API SetWinEventHook kills this process.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.FromComObject(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Gets accessible object from a COM object of any type that supports it. Returns null if fails.
member.param: Unmanaged COM object.
member.remarks: The COM object type can be IAccessible, IAccessible2, IHTMLElement, ISimpleDOMNode or any other COM interface type that can give IAccessible interface pointer through API IUnknown.QueryInterface or IServiceProvider.QueryService. For IHTMLElement and ISimpleDOMNode returns null if the HTML element is not an accessible object. Then you can try to get accessible object of its parent HTML element, parent's parent and so on, until succeeds.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.FromComObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Gets accessible object from a COM object of any type that supports it. Returns null if fails.
member.param: Managed COM object.
member.remarks: The COM object type can be IAccessible, IAccessible2, IHTMLElement, ISimpleDOMNode or any other COM interface type that can give IAccessible interface pointer through API IUnknown.QueryInterface or IServiceProvider.QueryService. For IHTMLElement and ISimpleDOMNode returns null if the HTML element is not an accessible object. Then you can try to get accessible object of its parent HTML element, parent's parent and so on, until succeeds. Also partially supports UIAutomationClient.IUIAutomationElement. Works with web page objects, but returns null for many other.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Acc._FuncId

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc._Hresult(Catkeys.Acc._FuncId,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls Native.SetError and returns hr. In Debug config also outputs error in red. If hr looks like not an error but just the property or action is unavailable, changes it to S_FALSE and does not show error. These are: S_FALSE, DISP_E_MEMBERNOTFOUND, E_NOTIMPL, for navigate also E_INVALIDARG, E_FAIL, E_NOINTERFACE.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.ToString

member.name: T:Catkeys.Acc.Misc
member.summary: Contains miscellaneous static Acc-related functions, rarely used or useful only for programmers.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Acc.Misc.MaxChildren
member.summary: When searching for an accessible object, if an intermediate object has more than this number of direct children, skip them and their descendants. This property is used by Acc.Find, Acc.Children, Acc.EnumChildren and similar functions. Valid values are 1000 to 1000000. Default 10000. Getting and comparing such large number of children is very slow. In extreme cases your app may hang or crash if there was no limit. For example OpenOffice Calc TABLE has one billion children. This property is thread-specific.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.ToUIElement
member.summary: Gets COM interface of UI Automation element corresponding to this accessible object. Returns null if cannot get.
member.remarks: Works with Firefox, Internet Explorer and some other windows. Does not work with Chrome and most other windows.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.HtmlAttribute(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets a HTML attribute or "".
member.param: Attribute name, for example "href", "id", "class". Full, case-sensitive.
Used only with Internet Explorer. If true, can get modified value, for example full URL instead of relative. If false (default), gets value as it is in HTML.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this is not a HTML element or does not have the specified attribute or failed. Supports . Works with these web browsers: Firefox (must be non-portable), Chrome (if Firefox is installed), Internet Explorer (slow), and browsers based on their code.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.HtmlAttributes(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets all HTML attributes.
member.param: Used only with Internet Explorer. If true, can get modified value, for example full URL instead of relative. If false (default), gets value as it is in HTML.
member.remarks: Returns empty dictionary if this is not a HTML element or does not have attributes or failed. Supports . Works with these web browsers: Firefox (must be non-portable), Chrome (if Firefox is installed), Internet Explorer (slow), and browsers based on their code.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.Match(System.Object[])
member.summary: Compares values of specified properties with specified strings. Also supports HTML attributes. Returns true if all match, false if at least one doesn't.
member.param: List of name/value pairs of properties and/or HTML attributes. Names must be of type string. Full, case-sensitive. Supported property names: "name" (), "value" (), "description" (). Names of HTML attributes must be with "a:" prefix, like "a:href". Supported are all attributes. Values can be of type string, or . Other types are converted to string. Strings are compared as case-insensitive wildcard (see . If fails to get a property or attribute (eg this HTML element does not have the attribute), its value is considered "". Example (1 property): "value", "*example*" Example (2 attributes): "a:class", "example", "a:href", "*/example.php*"
member.exception: Odd number of arguments. A name is null, "" or not string. A name is not one of supported property names and does not have "a:" prefix.
member.remarks: Also returns false if cannot get HTML attributes (when an attribute is specified), for example if this is not a HTML element. Then will return error code E_NOINTERFACE (0x80004002). Can get attributes from these web browsers: Firefox (must be non-portable), Chrome (if Firefox is installed), Internet Explorer (slow), and browsers based on their code.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.Html(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets HTML or "".
member.param: If true, gets outer HTML (with tag and attributes), else inner HTML.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this is not a HTML element or if failed. Supports . Works with these web browsers: Firefox (must be non-portable), Chrome (if is installed Firefox of same 32/64 bit), Internet Explorer (can be slow), and browsers based on their code. With Chrome slow if there are many descendant HTML elements. With Firefox and Chrome, this process must be of same 32/64 bit. If this is the root of web page (role DOCUMENT or PANE), get web page body HTML.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.ScrollTo
member.summary: Scrolls this accessible object into view.
member.exception: Failed to scroll, or the object does not support scrolling (then error "No such interface supported").
member.remarks: Supports web page elements in Internet Explorer, Firefox, Chrome and web browsers/controls based on their code. Also supports objects in some other windows, but in most window doesn't.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Acc.IHTMLElement.GetAttribute(System.String,System.Int32,System.String@)
member.param: If "class", calls get_className, else getAttribute.
0 interpolated, 1 match case (don't use), 2 raw.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Acc.ISimpleDOMNode
member.summary: We use this to get Firefox/Chrome HTML element attributes, HTML etc. rejected: find ISimpleDOMNode and convert to Acc, like QM2 FFNode/FindFF. Usually it is not significantly faster, sometimes much slower. For speed use UI Automation instead.

member.summary: Gets current text cursor (caret) rectangle in screen coordinates. Returns the control that contains it. If there is no text cursor or cannot get it (eg it is not a standard text cursor), gets mouse pointer coodinates and returns default(Wnd).

member.name: P:Catkeys.Input._KeyFunc.Plus
member.summary: + operator. Presses the key and does not release. These keys are auto-released after next key or (keys) that is not followed by +. Also after next mouse click. Example: "Ctrl+Shift+A ...". Example: "Alt+(F O) ...". Example: "Ctrl+" ... Mouse.Click() //Ctrl auto-released here.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Input._KeyFunc.Star
member.summary: * operator. 1. Repeats the preceding key. Example: "Tab*10" //press Tab 10 times. 2. Just presses (without releasing) or just releases. Example: "Ctrl*down" ... "Ctrl*up".

member.name: P:Catkeys.Input._KeyFunc.ParenStart
member.summary: ( operator. 1. Encloses function arguments. Example: WAIT(0.5). 2. Turns off auto-releasing keys pressed with operator +, until ")". Example: "Alt+(F O) ...". Example: "Ctrl+(" ... Mouse.Click(); Mouse.Click(); ... ")" //Ctrl released here.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Input._KeyFunc.ParenEnd
member.summary: ) operator. Releases keys pressed with operator +, when auto-releasing was turned off with operator (. See .

member.name: P:Catkeys.Input._KeyFunc.VK
member.summary: VK(vk, sc=0, ext=0) Sends key specified as virtual-key code and/or scan code. vk - virtual-key code. sc - optional scan code. ext - optional flags: 1 extended key.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Input._KeyFunc.CHAR
member.summary: CHAR(c) Sends a character using VK_PACKET. c - Unicode character code.

member.name: P:Catkeys.Input._KeyFunc.SLEEP
member.summary: SLEEP(t) Waits. t - number of milliseconds, eg 100.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Input.Misc
member.summary: Less-often used functions related to keyboard input.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Input.Misc.ReadKeyString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts keys string to Keys[] array.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Input.Misc.ReadHotkeyString(System.String,System.Windows.Forms.Keys@)
member.summary: Converts hotkey string to Keys. For example, if s is "Ctrl+Left", hotkey will be Keys.Left with modifier flag Keys.Control. Must be single non-modifier key, preceded by zero or more of modifier keys Ctrl, Shift, Alt, Win, all joined with +. Named keys must match case. Keys A-Z don't have to match case. Valid hotkey examples: "A", "a", "7", "F12", ".", "End", "Ctrl+D", "Ctrl+Alt+Shift+Win+Left", " Ctrl + U ". Invalid hotkey examples: null, "", "A+B", "Ctrl+A+K", "A+Ctrl", "Ctrl+Shift", "Ctrl+", "NoSuchKey", "end". Returns false if the string is invalid.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Input.Misc._KeyToModifier(System.Windows.Forms.Keys)
member.summary: If k is Shift, Control, Alt or Win (including left and right), returns it as modifier flag, eg Keys.Shift from Keys.ShiftKey. Else returns 0.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Input.Misc._KeynameToKey(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts part of string to Keys. The string should contain single key name, eg "Esc", "A", "=". Returns 0 if invalid key name.

member.name: T:Catkeys.ScreenImage
member.summary: Captures and finds images on screen.

member.name: M:Catkeys.ScreenImage.Capture(Catkeys.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Copies a rectangle of screen pixels to a new Bitmap object.
member.param: A rectangle in screen coordinates.
member.exception: Failed. Probably there is not enough memory for bitmap of specified size (need with*height*4 bytes).
member.remarks: PixelFormat is always Format32bppRgb.

member.name: M:Catkeys.ScreenImage.Capture(Catkeys.Wnd,Catkeys.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Copies a rectangle of window client area pixels to a new Bitmap object.
member.param: Window or control.
A rectangle in w client area coordinates. Use w.ClientRect to get whole client area.
member.exception: Failed. Probably there is not enough memory for bitmap of specified size (need with*height*4 bytes).
member.remarks: How this is different from : 1. Gets pixels from window's device context (DC), not from screen DC, unless the Aero theme is turned off (on Windows 7). The window can be under other windows. 2. If the window is partially or completely transparent, gets non-transparent image. 3. Does not work with Windows Store app windows (creates black image) and possibly with some other windows. 4. If the window is DPI-scaled, captures its non-scaled view. And rect must contain non-scaled coordinates.

member.name: M:Catkeys.ScreenImage.BitmapFromHbitmap(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates Bitmap from a GDI bitmap.
member.param: GDI bitmap handle. This function makes its copy.
member.remarks: How this function is different from Image.FromHbitmap: 1. Image.FromHbitmap usually creates bottom-up bitmap, which is incompatible with ScreenImage.Find and similar functions. This function creates normal top-down bitmap, like new Bitmap(...), Bitmap.FromFile(...) etc do. 2. This function always creates bitmap of Format32bppRgb PixelFormat.
member.exception: Failed. For example hbitmap is Zero.
Exceptions of Bitmap(int, int, PixelFormat) constructor.

member.name: M:Catkeys.ScreenImage.Find(System.Object,Catkeys.Types.SIArea,Catkeys.Types.SIFlags,System.Int32,System.Func{Catkeys.Types.SIResult,System.Boolean})
member.param: Image or color to find. Can be: string - path of .png or .bmp file. If not full path, uses . Also can use resources and embedded images; read in Remarks. Bitmap - image object in memory. int - color in 0xRRGGBB format. Alpha is not used. IEnumerable of string, Bitmap, int or object - multiple images or colors. Default action - find any. If flag AllMustExist - must find all.

Where to search. Can be a window/control, accessible object, Bitmap or a rectangle in screen.
Wnd - window or control. The search area is its client area.
Acc - accessible object.
Bitmap - another image. These flags are invalid: WindowDC.
RECT - a rectangle area in screen. These flags are invalid: WindowDC.
- can contain Wnd, Acc or Bitmap. Also allows to specify a rectangle in it, which makes the search area smaller and the function faster. Example: ScreenImage.Find("image.png", new SIArea(w, 100, 100, 100, 100));.

Maximal allowed color difference. Use to to find images that have slightly different colors than the specified image. Can be 0 - 250, but should be as small as possible. Applied to each color component (red, green, blue) of each pixel.

A callback function to call for each found image until it returns true. Can be used to create actions like "skip n matching images" (like also: t => t.MatchIndex == 1), "click all matching images" (also: t => { t.MouseClick(); Wait(0.5); return false; }), "get rectangles of all matching images" (also: t => { rectList.Add(t.Rect); return false; }), "ignore images that are or aren't in some custom areas", etc. When the callback function returns true, Find() returns result "found". Else Find() tries to find more matching images (towards the right and bottom) and calls the callback function again when found. If the callback function returns false every time, Find() returns result "not found".
member.exception: An argument is of unsupported type or is/contains a null/invalid value.
Exceptions of , Bitmap.LockBits. For example when the image file does not exist.
member.remarks:
If is file path, and the file does not exist, looks in resources of apdomain's entry assembly. For example, looks for Project.Properties.Resources.X if file "C:\\X.png" not found. Alternatively you can use code like using(var b = Project.Properties.Resources.X) ScreenImage.Find(b, w);.
can be string containing Base-64 encoded .png image file data with prefix "image:".
Some pixels in image can be transparent or partially transparent (AA of 0xAARRGGBB is not 255). These pixels are not compared.
The speed mostly depends on: 1. The size of the search area. Use the smallest possible area (control or accessible object or rectangle in window like new SIArea(w, r)). 2. Flag WindowDC (usually makes several times faster). With this flag the speed depends on window. 3. Video driver. Can be eg 10 times slower if incorrect or generic driver is used, for example on a virtual PC. Flag WindowDC should help. 4. colorDiff. Should be as small as possible.
If flag WindowDC is not used, the search area must be visible on the screen. If it is covered by other windows, the function will search in these windows.
The function can only find images that exactly match the specified image. With colorDiff it can find images with slightly different colors and brightness. It cannot find images with different shapes.
This function is not the best way to find objects when the script is intended for long use or for use on multiple computers or must be very reliable. Because it may fail to find the image after are changed some settings - system theme, application theme, text size (DPI), font smoothing (if the image contains text), etc. Also are possible various unexpected temporary conditions that may distort or hide the image, for example adjacent window shadow, a tooltip or some temporary window. If possible, in such scripts instead use other functions, eg find control or accessible object.
Throws ArgumentException if image or area is a bottom-up Bitmap object (see ). Such bitmaps are unusual in .NET (GDI+), but can be created by Image.FromHbitmap; instead use .

member.name: M:Catkeys.ScreenImage.WaitFor(System.Double,System.Object,Catkeys.Types.SIArea,Catkeys.Types.SIFlags,System.Int32,System.Func{Catkeys.Types.SIResult,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Waits for the specified image(s) or color(s) on the screen. Returns object containing the rectangle of the found image. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative (else exception).
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits indefinitely. If >0, after secondsTimeout time throws TimeoutException. If <0, after -secondsTimeout time returns null.
member.exception: Timeout. Thrown only when secondsTimeout is greater than 0.
member.remarks: Parameters and other info is the same as with .

member.name: M:Catkeys.ScreenImage.WaitNot(System.Double,System.Object,Catkeys.Types.SIArea,Catkeys.Types.SIFlags,System.Int32,System.Func{Catkeys.Types.SIResult,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Waits until the specified image(s) or color(s) is NOT found on the screen. Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative (else exception).
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits indefinitely. If >0, after secondsTimeout time throws TimeoutException. If <0, after -secondsTimeout time returns false.
member.remarks: Parameters and other info is the same as with .

member.name: M:Catkeys.ScreenImage.WaitChanged(System.Double,Catkeys.Types.SIArea,Catkeys.Types.SIFlags,System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits until something visually changes in a screen area. Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative (else exception).
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits indefinitely. If >0, after secondsTimeout time throws TimeoutException. If <0, after -secondsTimeout time returns false.
member.remarks: Parameters and other info is the same as with and . Instead of image parameter, this function captures the screen area image at the beginning.

member.summary: Gets object of the screen that contains the specified window (the biggest part of it) or is nearest to it. If w handle is 0 or invalid, gets the primary screen ( would return an invalid object if the window handle is invalid).

member.name: M:Catkeys.Screen_.FromObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Gets object by index or of the screen that contains (or is nearest to) the specified window, rectangle or point.
member.param:
Depends on type:
null: primary screen.
Screen: a object. If invalid, gets primary screen.
int: 1-based non-primary screen index (see ), or Screen_.Primary (0), Screen_.OfMouse (-1), Screen_.OfActiveWindow (-2).
Wnd: a window (see ). If invalid, gets primary screen.
Control: a .NET form or control (see ). If invalid, gets primary screen.
Point: a point (see ).
Rectangle, RECT: a rectangle (see ).
member.exception: Bad object type (not one from the above list).
member.remarks: If something fails (except if invalid index), gets primary screen. As screen index is used index in the array returned by + 1. It is not the screen index that you can see in Control Panel.

member.name: T:Catkeys.StringSegment
member.summary: An optimized representation of a substring.
member.remarks: A StringSegment variable holds a reference to the string containing the substring (), the start index of the substring () and substring length (). A new string object is allocated only by functions that return a string, eg . One of ways to create StringSegment instances is to split a string with . Functions throw ArgumentOutOfRangeException, ArgumentNullException or NullReferenceException exception when an argument is invalid. The indexer throws IndexOutOfRangeException. Don't use the default constructor. Then Buffer is null and the behavior of functions is undefined. Other constructors throw exception if the string is null.

member.name: T:Catkeys.String_
member.summary: Adds extension methods to System.String. Also adds StringComparison.Ordinal[IgnoreCase] versions of .NET String methods that use StringComparison.CurrentCulture by default. See https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms973919.aspx Extension method names have suffix _. Most of these extension methods throw NullReferenceException if called for a string variable that is null.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.Like_(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Compares this string with a string that possibly contains wildcard characters. Returns true if the strings match.
Wildcard characters: * - zero or more of any characters. ? - any character.
member.param: This string. If null, returns false. If "", returns true if pattern is "" or "*".
String that possibly contains wildcard characters. Cannot be null. If "", returns true if this string is "". If "*", always returns true except when this string is null.
Case-insensitive.
member.remarks: Like all String_ functions, performs ordinal comparison, ie does not depend on current culture. Much faster than Regex.IsMatch and not much slower than Equals_, EndsWith_, IndexOf_ etc.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.Like_(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String[])
member.summary: Calls for each wildcard pattern specified in the argument list until it returns true. Returns 1-based index of matching pattern, or 0 if none.
member.param: Case-insensitive.
One or more wildcard strings. The array and strings cannot be null.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt32_(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Converts part of string to int. Returns the int value, or 0 if fails to convert. Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big. Unlike int.Parse and Convert.ToInt32: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. Supports hexadecimal format, like "0x1E" or "0x1e". Much faster.
member.param: Offset in this string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.remarks: The number can begin with ASCII spaces, tabs or newlines, like " 5". The number can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- uint.MaxValue (0xffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than int.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to uint (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=1.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt32_(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameter numberEndIndex.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt32_(System.String)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameters.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt64_(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Converts part of string to long. Returns the long value, or 0 if fails to convert. Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big. Unlike long.Parse and Convert.ToInt64: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. Supports hexadecimal format, like "0x1E" or "0x1e". Much faster.
member.param: Offset in this string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.remarks: The number can begin with ASCII spaces, tabs or newlines, like " 5". The number can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- ulong.MaxValue (0xffffffffffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than long.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffffffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to ulong (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=1.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt64_(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameter numberEndIndex.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToInt64_(System.String)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameters.

member.name: M:Catkeys.String_.ToIntAndString_(System.String,System.Int32@,System.String@,System.Int32)
member.summary: If this string contains a number at startIndex, gets that number as int, also gets the string part that follows it, and returns true. For example, for string "25text" or "25 text" gets num = 25, tail = "text". Everything else is the same as with .
member.param: Receives the number. Receives 0 if no number.
Receives the string part that follows the number, or "". Receives null if no number. Can be this variable.
Offset in this string where to start parsing.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Util.LibArrayBuilder`1
member.summary: Like List or StringBuilder, used as a temporary variable-size array to create final fixed-size array. To avoid much garbage (and many reallocations when growing), uses native memory heap. See . Must be explicitly disposed to free the native memory. Does not have a finalizer because is struct (to avoid garbage). Does not support reference types. Does not call Dispose.

member.name: M:Catkeys.Util.LibArrayBuilder`1.ReAlloc(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds or removes elements at the end. Sets Count=count. Preserves Math.Min(Count, count) existing elements. Returns memory address (address of element 0).
member.param: New element count.
Set all added bytes = 0. If false, the added memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Default true. Slower when true.
member.remarks: The new memory usually is at a new location. The preserved elements are copied there. Sets Count=count. To allocate more memory without changing Count, change Capacity instead.

member.name: T:Catkeys.Util.StringCache
member.summary: Caches managed strings created from unmanaged char* buffers.
member.remarks: Can be used in possibly very frequently called functions to avoid much string garbage and frequent garbage collections. For example, Wnd.ClassName and Wnd.Name use this. They are called by Wnd.Find for each window (can be hundreds of them). And WaitFor.WindowExists calls Wnd.Find every 30 or so milliseconds. It could create megabytes of garbage (window classname and name strings) in a few seconds. Every Wnd.Find call creates almost the same set of strings, therefore it makes sense to cache them. To allow GC free the cached strings, use a WeakReferenc<StringCache> object. See example.

member.summary: Searches in the cache for a managed string that matches unmanaged string p of length len. If finds, returns it. Else adds new string(p, 0, len) to the cache and returns it.
member.param: Unmanaged string.
p length.
member.remarks: speed when found in cache: similar to new string(p, 0, len).

p length.
Call len = LibCharPtr.Length(p, len).

member.name: T:Catkeys.Util.LibProcessMemory
member.summary: Memory shared by all appdomains of current process. Size 0x10000 (64 KB). Initially zero.
member.remarks: When need to prevent simultaneous access of the memory by multiple threads, use lock("uniqueString"){...} . It locks in all appdomains, because literal strings are interned, ie shared by all appdomains. Using some other object with 'lock' would lock only in that appdomain. Maybe except Type. Use this only in single module, because ngened modules have own interned strings.
